title: Design facilitation strategy for Dec 5 faculty AI session
Build embedding-based ethnographic auto-coding demo tool
description: Built complete Streamlit app for Dec 5 faculty demo: bulk file upload (.txt/.docx/.pdf/.rtf/.csv), OpenAI embeddings, k-means clustering with auto-detect, LLM-generated theme labels, UMAP visualization, export functionality. Includes sample data, demo script (4-act structure), and human/AI contribution breakdown. Active build time: 15-20 min over 40 min session. Location: ~/knowledge-work/projects/ai-ucsb-strategy/embeddings-demo/

Build statistical consensus workflow analysis platform
description: Production-grade system for analyzing workflows with statistical rigor. Goes beyond Teamraderie workshop manual prompts to provide: N-iteration analysis (N=50), aggregated metrics with confidence intervals, stability scores (HIGH/MEDIUM/LOW CV), variance-based flagging of ambiguous data. Architecture: parallel execution engine (asyncio), metric extraction layer (regex+LLM fallback), statistical aggregation (numpy/scipy), Streamlit UI. 16-week plan: experimental design (optimal N), MVP development, customer pilot (3-5 orgs), production readiness. Cost: ~$0.01/analysis @ 50 iterations. Location: ~/knowledge-work/projects/workflow-analysis-platform/. See README.md, ARCHITECTURE.md, PILOT_PLAN.md for details.

title: ChatGPT analyze mid-class and end-of-class entries
Automation Architectures paper: Theoretical contribution assessment
description: Assessed whether paper offers same level of contribution as 'option cultivation' or 'misfit motivates'. Finding: Current version is descriptive (documents heterogeneity, provides typology) but lacks strong theoretical mechanism. Identified gap: 'automation architectures' is a label, not a theory. Proposed solution: Frame around organizational learning literature (exploration/exploitation across units, multi-site learning, Ferdows factory roles). Key insight: Prior automation research assumes uniform treatment effects; this paper shows firms intentionally differentiate facility roles. Same technology serves different purposes at different nodes.

title: PB qualitative data analysis for automation architectures
description: Searched PB interview data for evidence of intentional facility role differentiation. Key findings: (1) Ryan explicitly describes tier-1 vs tier-2 site distinction for automation deployment; (2) Sandra describes volume thresholds for technology choice (600+ destinations = EuroSort, <200 = Ambidextrous); (3) Pilot sites chosen for vendor proximity + lower stakes; (4) 'Gallatin develops, Fresno perfects' pattern confirmed in Gap data. Evidence supports multi-site learning frame. Location: PB Qual Data in warehouse-automation-papers/all_data/

title: Option Cultivation paper: Add Sandra's quote as managerial misconception
description: Added Sandra Rago's quote ('you can see the exodus in the data 2 months prior') to Option Cultivation paper as example of flawed managerial mental model. Quant data shows opposite: floor workers stayed (option cultivation), only managers fled. Added to Communication About Automation section + For Managers discussion. Strengthens practical contribution by showing managers' fear of exodus is unfounded for floor workers facing uncertain automation. Created new Overleaf zip: option_cultivation_overleaf_20251126.zip

title: Facility size × automation interaction test
description: Wrote and ran test based on A1's observation that smaller facilities perform better with automation. RESULT: Statistically significant (p=0.001). Small facilities see -4.8% PPH effect; large facilities see -18.6% PPH effect. Difference of +17% favoring small facilities. Supports A1's hypothesis about scale diseconomies in automation (coordination/communication complexity). Script: paper2/analysis/facility_size_interaction_test.py

title: Volume variance by facility role test (Thompson buffering)
description: Wrote and ran test of Thompson's buffering hypothesis: expansion nodes should have higher demand variance (CV) than efficiency nodes. RESULT: Not supported. Expansion and efficiency nodes have nearly identical CV (~0.59). Shrink nodes have lower variance (0.41). Thompson buffering is NOT the right theoretical lens for automation architectures. Alternative explanations needed: Focused Factory (Skinner), capacity portfolio, or organizational learning (exploration/exploitation). Script: paper2/analysis/volume_variance_by_role_test.py

title: Automation architectures: Identify theoretical literature
description: Searched for organizational learning literature to ground 'automation architectures' concept. Identified 20+ key papers across 5 streams: (1) Cross-unit learning (Argote, Szulanski, Darr); (2) Exploration/exploitation (March 1991, Tushman & O'Reilly ambidexterity); (3) Multi-plant strategy (Ferdows 1997 factory roles); (4) Technology implementation as learning (Edmondson, Pisano); (5) Knowledge transfer barriers (Carlile, von Hippel sticky information). Key frame: Firms assign different LEARNING ROLES to different facilities—pilot sites explore, optimization sites exploit. Gap execs explicitly use this language. Updated agent suite to require literature (not single paper) for theoretical lens.

title: Update agent suite: Require literature not single paper for theoretical lens
description: Identified anti-pattern in agent suite: was anchoring theoretical lens on single paper (e.g., Thompson 1967). Modified /find-lens command in paper-mining-agents to require a LITERATURE (body of work with multiple papers, minimum 5 citations) for any theoretical framing. Added explicit anti-pattern warning about anchoring on single papers. Updated Canonical Citations section to require foundational, empirical, and review papers. Location: paper-mining-agents/.claude/commands/find-lens.md

title: Solve and Be Seen ILR revision strategy
description: Analyzed full submission history (ASQ R1 → ASQ reject → ASR → OrgSci → ILR). Core reviewer concern: technology feels like backdrop not mechanism; mismatch between front-end framing and findings. Produced revision memo for coauthors covering: (1) tighten tech connection in all cases esp Lucía, (2) show post-visibility skill development evidence, (3) define specialized skill upfront, (4) fix methods gaps, (5) acknowledge alternative explanations, (6) respond to R2's alternative reading, (7) cut 3,300 words. Division of labor proposed: Dan=methods, Matt=framing+cases, Danielle=lit+response letter. Deadline mid-February.

title: TM464 Monte Carlo grading system: Full pipeline completion
description: Built and ran complete automated grading pipeline for TM464 Fall 2025 course using Monte Carlo multi-run approach with Claude Sonnet. Completed: (1) Fixed 12k→25k char truncation bug in consistency.py (2) Cloned 49 GitHub Classroom repos for AI repo assignment (3) Created rubrics: shared_ai_repo.json (80pts/5 criteria), shared_ai_repo_written.json (10pts) (4) Built git repo loader in loader.py (5) Graded all assignment types: 3x3x3 learning plans (48), AI repo markdown (46), Written Analysis (47), Lean PRD Sprint 2 (10 teams), Skill Impact Sprint 2 (10 teams), late submissions (4) (6) Processed manual lightning talk grades (individual + team) (7) Merged all grades into Canvas gradebook CSV with fuzzy name matching (8) Applied team grades using roster from Canvas screenshots. Total ~200 submissions graded across 6 assignment types.

title: Grade review HTML app for human-AI calibration
description: Built local HTML app for systematic review of AI-graded submissions. Features: (1) Stratified sampling by risk - prioritizes high variance, boundary scores, outliers (2) 161 submissions in review queue sorted by priority (3) Three-panel layout: submission list, rubric reference, detail view with AI ratings (4) Tabs for AI ratings vs full content (5) Review workflow: agree/adjust/flag with score delta tracking (6) Keyboard shortcuts for rapid review (7) localStorage persistence (8) JSON export with summary stats. Serves via python http.server. User modified HTML to add rubric panel, link extraction, and improved layout.
